Roti.question: You own a popular boutique in a local market & your designs are loved in your neighbourhood. You know you are good with fashion & design. You can start your own label and sell your own branded outfits.

options.text: Never, I am happy with my current business.
Sometimes, I am uncertain to make such a big decision.
Always, I would start my own label one day.

Roti.question: You want to start your Lassi (Food & Beverages) shop in a university campus to attract students, what is your first choice of place to set up the shop? How would you fund it?

options.text: Rent out a property on the main campus, though it costs more, it would be profitable. Thus, I would spend my savings, and borrow from a financial institution, family & friends.
Rent out a property in the corner because it is affordable, look for main road shops only when profits come
Start the business on vending truck, and wait for the time when there are enough funds to rent/buy a full shop

Roti.question: Your  distant  relative  left  youRs.500,000 in  her  will.  How  do  you  plan  to utilize  itfor  your business?

options.text: Buy a new scooter/other utility for operations at work.
Use for shop renovation and improvement to grow business
Deposit all the money in savings account and use them on a rainy-day

Roti.question: You are run afurniture shop, though are facing competition because of online stores coming in. You feel unsure. What to do?

options.text: I will quit my business and look for a job under a big carpenter/contractor or a furniture brand
I will put my furniture on e-commerce stores and compete on the quality of my products
I will market my product with a new positioning, handmade, artistic and unique. Give offers to my loyal customers, put myself on Google my Business, etc.
I will continue to do quality work, my work will compete with the competition

Roti.question: Growing up you always wanted to land on a govt. job,but as you grew, you realized, you wanted to be your own boss. What does it take to start a micro-business?

options.text: Funds/Financial Backing
Passion/Creativity/Ideas
Necessity/Strong will
Business acumen/ Skills

Kapda.question: Wonder if you know what is insurance, credit, payments?

options.text: I know credit, insurance & payments.
I know credit & insurance but not payments
I know credit, not insurance or payments

Kapda.question: You  have  made  financial  decisions  on  investment,  insurance,  etc.  for  yourself,  they  will  be based on:

options.text: Entirely driven by will
Entirely driven by research from friends, family, internet, company, etc.
Based on family will and some research
researchI do not make investments, insurance for myself, only by family

Kapda.question: Your neighbour lost a lot of money in the share market, what would you advise him?

options.text: Not to invest in share markets, it is not for us. My neighbour was a fool to get his hands dirty.
Not to invest in share markets unless you have researched about it well
Shares can be risky, but they can give high returns. Not to worry and seek advice from an expert friend next time before any investments
Not to invest in share markets, utilize that money in your business for returns.

Kapda.question: You earned Rs. 20,000 surplus profits during the festival season. Whether to spend on your Pooja store or buy a shop insurance protection that your brother-in-law is pitching?

options.text: My Pooja store has a lot of inflammable material, I’ll purchase a shop insurance this time, also, happy brother-in-law, Happy Wife, Happy Life!
I’ll colour my Pooja store red, no need of any useless insurance scheme.
I’ll do a simple FD, best to save money when you have it.

Kapda.question: Your health insurance claim did not come yet, you shouldn’t have taken any insurance from anyone. How would you tackle this situation?

options.text: I will consider it as my fate and pledge not to take any further insurance policies from anyone.
I will contact the insurer and seek help, if no help arrives, I’ll contact the regulators
I will file police complain against the insurer.

Makaan.question: You have Rs.500 per month to invest, but, your financial decisions are generally taken by your husband/son/consultant/advisor because they are more aware than you are.

options.text: Disagree, I manage my own business, I will invest in buying goods for my store
Neutral, I might give it to them to invest, or can save it myself
Strongly agree, my husband/son can invest better

Makaan.question: You balance your spending with savings for tomorrow for the future.

options.text: Neutral, I will save& spendaccording to personal & household goalsat home
Somewhat Disagree, I am an intuitive spender
Agree, I will save in a bankto earn interests& feel at peace

Makaan.question: You hail from Firozabad, the city famous for glass work. Lately, you are facing competition due to trendy bangle designs in metal & plastic. How do you plan to address the competition?

options.text: I will quit my business and look for a job under a big manufacturer’s shop/factory
I will put my neighbourhood bangles on e-commerce stores and compete on the quality of my products
I will market my product as handmade, artistic, and unique. Give offers to my loyal customers, put myself on Google my Business, etc.

Makaan.question: This year, your farms harvested tonnes of mangoes for you to sell, though the market is already full of mangoes. What happens to prices when the supply is high &the demand is low?

options.text: Prices increase
Prices decrease
Prices remain the same

Makaan.question: You are a conservative investor, thus always looking for low risk and high returns. Which of the following options will NOT give you a guaranteed investment?

options.text: Savings Account and/or money in my Galla
SIP, mutual funds, ULIP Insurance Schemes pitched by my friends
Investing in my business

Internet.question: Your favourite thing to watch on YouTube today?

options.text: New recipes to cook and/or new designs to make
My favourite serial, Reels or Tik-Tok
I do not watch YouTube often, my husband/son has the phone

Internet.question: You are scared of those smartphone-based payments.

options.text: Disagree, I am always on the phone
Neutral, I can use it for my basic needs
Strongly agree, my kids know all about these devices

Internet.question: When was the last time you did a UPI payment at any store/shop? Do you prefer to keep a QR code in your shop?

options.text: Yes, it is the need these days, I pay via UPI often.
No, our life generally prefers cash
Yes, but not so often, I am a little cautious in using internet

Internet.question: Your husband recommends you to use a famous record keeping app to maintain your Galla, what is your answer to him?

options.text: I am using my register and pen, and it is serving me well.
OK, teach me how to use the app, I will give it a try if it is in Hindi.
I am already using the application. Thank You
I don’t need to do accounting, our shop is a small set-up we don’t need it

Internet.question: You neighbouring shopkeeper pays his EMIs through his bank account, but you have to visit bank branches. To change this, what can be done by you?

options.text: I’ll ask the branch employees to get my bank deduction process initiated
I am going to fill out my form for bank deductions after I understand the whole process and ensure safety.
Nothing, I prefer security over ease. I will do cash payments
